awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides partial support for participants in the 2019 East Coast Operator Algebra Symposium (ECOAS), which will be held on the campus of The Ohio State University October 12-13, 2019. The symposium expects between 50-70 participants, including many graduate students and postdocs. This will be the seventeenth annual meeting in the East Coast Operator Algebra Symposium series. The first meeting was held at Vanderbilt University in Nashville in the Fall of 2003, and since then, meetings have been held each Fall. 

The conference focuses on operator algebras (C* and von Neumann algebras) and non-commutative geometry, with applications to a wide array of disciplines, including ergodic theory, number theory, representation theory, and mathematical physics. The ECOAS enables participants to become acquainted with the forefront of research in operator algebras and non-commutative geometry and neighboring disciplines, while also providing early-career researchers with the opportunity to present their own work, and network and interact with each other along with senior researchers. More information can be found at the conference website: https://people.math.osu.edu/penneys.2/ECOAS2019.html

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The seventeenth East Coast Operator Algebra Symposium (ECOAS) was held at The Ohio State University on October 12-13, 2019. The ECOAS is an important annual conference in operator algebras which showcases recent breakthroughs in active areas of research. Typically, this conference centers on research from C^*-algebras, von Neumann algebras, and non-commutative geometry. The conference places a significant emphasis on participation from early career researchers, especially graduate students and postdocs. In particular, many talks are given by early career researchers to enhance their visibility, and funding is prioritized for early career researchers to help them meet senior mathematicians in the area, forge collaborations, and learn the most up-to-date advances in the field. The plenary speakers, affiliations at the time of the conference, and their talk titles are listed below:

José Carrión, TCU, Classifying *-homomorphisms

Jorge Castillejos, KU Leuven, Regularity properties for nuclear C^*-algebras

Ian Charlesworth, UC Berkeley, Matrix models for epsilon-independence

Cain Edie-Michell, Vanderbilt, A classification of fusion categories generated by an object of dimension (1+\sqrt{5})/2

Carla Farsi, U Colorado, Spectral triples, wavelets, and higher rank graphs

Mahya Ghandehari, U Delaware, Spectra of (weighted) Fourier algebras

Sherry Gong, UCLA, The Novikov conjecture, the group of volume preserving diffeomorphisms, and Hilbert-Hadamard spaces

Alexander Gorokhovsky, U Colorado, Cyclic cohomology and higher indices

Brent Nelson, MSU, Free stein irregularity and dimension

Pieter Spaas, UCLA, Central sequences and their applications

Zhizhang Xie, TAMU, Secondary invariants in noncommutative geometry and their applications

The speakers included a mix of senior researchers, early career researchers, and postdocs. There were 3 women speakers and 4 speakers total from underrepresented groups. Overall, there were 48 participants, with at least 8 from underrepresented groups.


Leftover funds from the ECOAS award were used to support graduate students working on projects in the scope of the ECOAS conference.


Last Modified: 01/05/2022
Modified by: David S Penneys
